A quadratic residue modulo n is an integer that is congruent to a perfect square modulo n. To find all quadratic residues modulo 13, we need to compute the squares of the numbers from 0 to 12 (since 13 is a prime number) and then reduce them modulo 13.

0^2 ≡ 0 (mod 13)
1^2 ≡ 1 (mod 13)
2^2 ≡ 4 (mod 13)
3^2 ≡ 9 (mod 13)
4^2 ≡ 16 ≡ 3 (mod 13)
5^2 ≡ 25 ≡ 12 (mod 13)
6^2 ≡ 36 ≡ 10 (mod 13)
7^2 ≡ 49 ≡ 10 (mod 13)
8^2 ≡ 64 ≡ 12 (mod 13)
9^2 ≡ 81 ≡ 3 (mod 13)
10^2 ≡ 100 ≡ 4 (mod 13)
11^2 ≡ 121 ≡ 1 (mod 13)
12^2 ≡ 144 ≡ 9 (mod 13)

Now, we can list the distinct residues obtained: {0, 1, 3, 4, 9, 10, 12}. These are the quadratic residues modulo 13.
